comment:
Nose:
Stewed apples, applesauce, malty sweetness, slight cinnamon

Palate:
Less apple than the nose, creamy sweetness, floral, almost slightly hoppy

Finish:
Short, floral, sweet
It tastes of whiskey, and that's fine.

Vanilla and honey on the nose, with light orchard florals that lurk in the background. Honey is immediate on the tongue followed quickly by sweet cream butter and brown bread which make up the primary body. Light florals at the end give way to a bitter astringency that lingers momentarily. All in all, a decent sipping whiskey.
Woody, light fruit, and warming. Smoother than Glenfiddich.

Much more complex than I remember. Bananas, butterscotch, butter popcorn on the nose. Sweet and standard speyside profile on the palate. Little spice with a big enough sip. Quite good for the price. 

12 USD per (again very generous) pour
Abbey Rd Pub
Va Beach
A bit less smooth, but fuller, smoky taste.
Very smooth can’t put my finger on the smell I would say aroma is like pears or cereal the taste is vanilla and fruity no burn at all which is a plus

The nose of the whiskey is dominated by the scent of oranges, just at the end there is a sweet note of honey and a faint whisp of smoke.  It is reminiscent of an Old Fashioned.

On the tongue the scotch is light with a sweet twist of orange followed by a light hint of peat.  There is a honeyed sweetness throughout.

By far and away my favorite scotch to date.
Light on the nose, with a taste that lingers for a while.
Nose is dominated by butterscotch with some honey, brown sugar, and banana in the background. Palate is sweet with apples and vanilla. Finish is short and crisp.
Smooth drinker, little heat and sweet notes

향 : 부즈없이 상쾌한 꽃향, 가벼운향, 옅은향, 
맛 : 옅은쌉쌀, 약한 배, 오일리하지 않음, 배껍질, 가벼운 쓴맛
피니쉬 : 쌉쌀함이 옅게, 

전체적으로 옅어 아쉬움

NOSE: Very light and fruity. Pears. Rock melon. Honey. That’s it. Oddly no vanilla at all.

PALATE: Sweet melon transitions into some ginger spice and more pear. Short but balanced.

OVERALL: Just a simple, classic whisky. Not complex but very rounded without any harsh edges.
Slightly oaky. Smooth with a little burn. Vanilla, tobacco. Quite nice. No ice Cube needed.
Im tasting the ‘new’ version with the seafoam green label and ‘double wood’ description. What can I say? It’s a solid non-sherried Speyside single malt. Rich honey/vanilla/malt flavors. It’s good.
Very smooth. Sweet, warm, floral taste. Pleasant, mild aftertaste.

Though I enjoy the more light grassy and honey dew aspects of this Speyside, there is a lingering taste and smell that reminds me of something sweet that has gone spoiled. I can't quite put my finger on it but, after trying it several times, have decided that it is one of the very few whisk(e)ys I would turn down when offered a free pour.
Sweeter nose and taste. No peat but good
Vanilla fruity notes on smell. Some leathery, earthy scents. Grassy, floral tastes with some bite. Some peat on the finish. Easy drinker
Basic and good. Solid whiskey. Nothing special.

Nose - sweet smelling, hints of fresh apples among other fruity scents. Slightly oaky.

Flavour - Rich and delicate, almost silky as it hits the tongue. The sweetness of the fruits are there, but lacks a lasting flavour. Smooth finish as it washes down.
This is just an easy drinker for sure. Not too boring with the notes of honey and vanilla, but not too complex.

My first scotch. 

Nose is very sweet with lots of fruit and caramel scents. 

Taste has lots of honey flavor with some fruit and vanilla on the back end. 

Very smooth. Greatly enjoyed it.
Decent speyside.  Nothing to write home about, but not disappointed either.
Smooth and a hint of peat with definite vanilla notes.

Thanks for the Scotch James! Pear perfume on the nose, in a good way, great mouth feel, strong honey, medium finish. Slight nasal heat with a black pepper aftertaste. Little to no smoke. Very smooth short medium finish.

Sweet overripe apple, pear, spice, and light oak on the nose. A little vanilla in there too if you’re looking for it.

Flavor is more sweet fruit, smooth and easy drinking. Doesn’t linger, short and sweet.
Vanilla and peach give way to oak and a bit of spice. Short finish. Nothing complex to figure out just balanced and tasty.
Vanilla, pecan, barrel spice, really opens up with a bit of water.
Not normally a scotch fan, but this was smooth.
A more mild Glenfiddich 12.  Not as much pear but it's still there. A enjoyable drink.
Not such a fan of scotch. Harsh, very smoky
There's a reason this is ubiquitous.  It's a nice, relaxing drink scotch that is utterly dependable.

A classic simple sipper. Nothing shocking or extreme, but pleasant and inviting.

Nose: sweet vanilla
Palate: Vanilla followed by apple sauce and fresh cut grass, and I tiny spice.
Finish: short, light, and vanilla
I Drink lots of different scotch, bourbon and whiskey. High cost, low cost, highly rated and whatever. This is Hands down my go to of them all whenever I want to just enjoy a solid dram.
Citrus nose. Spicy fruits through the taste. The spice continues into finish in a very pleasant and warming way.
Gold in color. Fruity sweet aroma. Slight burn going down, warm finish.

Light gold color, slight astringency scent.  Burns the nose at first sniff, but with hints of fruit or berry aromas in the back.

Sweet taste, less burn going down than just after.
просто норм віскі без залишкових смаків нейтральне
Just didn’t like it really. Smooth but a little alcohol-y.

Nose : Delicate Florals, Orange Peel, mild acidic astringency.

Palate : Tart Foreground, Black pepper spice, short mellow.

Had this before but never formally reviewed. This is well known readily available scotch which can be a good thing. Poured neat, nose is ripe red apple, mild spice and barrel with barley malt. Standard speyside if you will. Pleasant and inoffensive. Palate is more of the same with fruity notes along with light malt, spice , and wood however a flash of gentle peat is there. Finish is drying malt and wood with lingering overtones of fruit and maybe a hint of smoke. This is just a nice plain jane single malt. Think of it as scotch training wheels till your ready to jump in the deep end. Seems to be a bit overpriced in some markets(I paid $41) but I have to say this stuff delivers a basic smooth scotch experience without any off notes or scary heavy peat for newcomers. If you have been around the block this will probably bore you but I still appreciate for what it offers........80/100.........Yes this is a long review for a relatively average scotch but I think its important to give some love to these gateway single malts that can lead down the path so to speak...... I do like the new packaging as well

Smooth, not too complex.  Nice dram that can be enjoyed neat, on the rocks, or mixed.  Unlike most purists, I enjoy the new labeling. At this price point, I however prefer the Singleton of Glendullan 12, as it adds an additional complexity that the Glenlivet 12 lacks.
Light, fruit, sweet, not complex but also not terrible.

I'm a newbie so I'm still learning a lot. This was easy to sip, very smooth. I couldn't put my finger on the honey notes till I read a little more about it in the Distiller profile. Perfect for a night cap.
Great drinkable Scotch. Light and slightly fruity. Affordable and delicious.

Nose- rose, hisbiscus, dew
Mouth feel- light non-viscous
Taste- rose water, clove, pineapple, slate
Very smooth. Double oak makes a difference
Earthy notes on the taste. With a slight smokiness to it. Hints of vanilla and leather on the nose

Nose: honey, vanilla, sherry notes
Palate: sweet, balanced and light 
Finish: nothing that really lingers - maybe some spice
Fruit and cereal are the prominent notes. Pear and some nectarine in particular. Very smooth going down but not an exciting dram. Finish still has some fruit that lingers a little.

Hints of field corn among the well balanced nose.   Nothing jumps out, but it's all there.  Light peat, honey, pear and toast, cinnamon hard candies.
Palate is where the peat comes through. Cornflakes in among the salty and dry oak.

Some Honey, some vanilla, floral. A bit difficult to drink at first. After taste a bit short. Conclusion:  Ok scotch..

Follow me on insta: @whiskperience
Neat, from the bar: Vanilla off the bat, maple and sugary malts. Nice smoke, mild burn but the peat softens it. Really well balanced with the peat and the malt sweetness trading places.
Very smooth with hints of flowers and honey. A little bitter on the back end. Very good with a nice nose and great tongue feel.

Neat, at the bar: Burn is legit. Less peaty than I remember it. Corn, caramel, toffee, vanilla, the uzh. Hint of salt. I have a cold so idk if that is coloring my enjoyment one way or the other. It's just very pleasant, and gives a nice warming glow from my insides.

On the nose you can find butterscotch, honey, brown sugar, and banana behind a medicinal aroma not unlike DayQuil. The palate is sweet with apples, vanilla, brown sugar, and more medicinal flavors. Followed by medium length crisp finish with a little spice. 

This is a very sweet scotch that can be welcoming for new scotch drinkers, but I do rank it behind the other Glens.
Nose is sweet, honey. Initial taste doesn’t have much flavor but I’ve been drinking mostly barrel proof lately so 40% is pretty low ALC. Spicier later taste, with some peaty notes
Good nose, but way too sweet and immature.

So smooth. 
Hanging with my son listening to Blue Steel Harts.

Decent
 Very much like regular Glenlivet. Useful as a mixer with soda.

Light sweet Honey 
Smooth easy to drink

A little better than I remember. Ordered at bar while waiting on my Sushi order. In rocks glass, big notes of malted cereal grains, apple and honey on the nose. The palate has more smoke than I remember and almost a medicinal note? If this were a blend, I’d swear there was some peated whisky in there somewhere. Apple and pear. Honey.  Nice tingly finish with vanilla and charred wood coating the palate. Not as much bitterness as I remember from my initial tasting. Maybe I should revisit this one more often.
Honey and malt on the nose, light and fruity taste. Little bit of burn and oak spice on the finish.
Light smoke great spring or summer scotch. Supper light for 12.

Excellent value for money. Not overly complex, nor does it have a long finish, but the orchard fruits and hints of vanilla come through on both the nose and the palate to provide an easy-sipping dram that’s just fine for most people who just want a Speyside Scotch in the $35 to $40 range. Buy it — you won’t be disappointed.

Nose - Tons of apple and some honeydew, a sweet vanilla undertone. 
Taste - Fruit tones dropped off and vanilla took over. Moderately lingering finish

Nose - honey, grape, green apple, pear, white wine, vanilla, slightly floral, corn, light oak. 

Taste - honey, vanilla, apple/pear, finishing quick and a bit sour.

For having such a delicate nose (and being only 80 proof), this has a large bite that is a bit off-putting. Overall, I’m not a fan.
My first Scotch. My dads go to.
Smooth and tasty easy drinker with lush fruity melon and apricot flavours and strong vanilla, honey and mead. Light and lovely.
A perfectly average scotch for a simple drink kind of evening. Strong vanilla honey on the nose then toasted oat and oak on the palate.

Nose: raisins dipped in light milk chocolate, fresh cut apple, dark non-liquid honey, plum jam, floral and oily oak, bid of vanilla

Palate: sweet in the beginning, a slight chili sensation, a good amount of dark chocolate

Finish: wood and ongoing dark chocolate, slightly dry

I must say I enjoyed this one. It definitely is an interesting dram that has to offer different chapters that stand out from each other. But it definitely doesn’t overwhelm with a lot of variety. This whisky offers just a few aspects but those it does deliver very well and convincing. The only real downside is that it feels too „rocky“ midway through the palate until the end of the finish - rocky in „hard, dry and rough“. I miss some roundness that would bring it together.
A lot of flavor without the peat. Very good

Noses with pears, sugary juice and a bit of citrus. Hits the palate with that juiciness, vanilla, oak and light fruit, very smooth and light. Enjoyable neat on a hot evening, I can see it doing well in a highball too.
Excellent single malt at the sub $30 price point.  Off a freshly opened bottle, its a little spicy.   Rounds out a bit after breathing in the glass.   Tasted neat.  Great value.
Vanilla toasted cereal and a little bit of honey. Easy drinking and that’s just fine. Very approachable.
Vanilla and a little honey. Easy to drink and that’s just fine.
Easy to drink. Vanilla, toasted , and a little bit of fruit.
On the nose I get some pear and a little mild apple. Pear continues on the mouth with a fade to a light vanilla.
Always been a fan of Glenlivet.. pairing it with a La Gloria Cubana Serie R Esteli
Mild with very strong flavors of vanilla and honey. Extremely easy drinking.
Apple, pears and a little musty note on the nose. Sweet round palate. A hint of spice on the medium finish.
Very nice and easy to drink.  Great apple finish that lingers and subtle fruit on the taste
It's a fine scotch and not distinctive enough to love or hate

Flowery, heather sweet.  Must be all bourbon-cask matured.  Not a hint of sherry.  Mild, pleasant, but forgettable.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
Really fruity and sweet on the nose. Honeyed apricots and pear. On the palette, it’s smooth and easy to drink. A touch of heat and spice at the end. Overall, a nice easy drinker.
Very smoky flavoring. Not my favorite but if you like smokiness in your scotch, you’ll probably like it.

Nose: lemon, cider, honey, cinnamon, vanilla

Palate: oak, pear, apples, vanilla

Finish: dry
Enjoying this on my patio on a beautiful Easter Sunday. Such a day deserves such a wonderful Scotch. Cheers!

Nose
Floral, grassy, pear

Palate
Pear
Honey
Vanilla 
Black tea
Grassy
Eh, it's ok. I'd never pay for it again.

Not bad, but nothing I love on first bottle opening. Online ads say this is the same, but side by side tasting does not equal the original. It seems to be missing the cereal and bananas component. Not as smooth.

Bought a little taster of this at the local liquor store just to try it.

Nose: it’s got a citrusy smell on the initial waft. Smells like a fizzy citrus, almost cleaning supply citrus. Raisins, nail polish, pears.

Taste: pear, light honey, slightly nutty beginning, does this weird thing where the moment you open up your mouth it goes peppery and slightly oaky, and gives you this slight smoke. It’s got a spicy cinnamon finish. 

Mouthfeel: watery, not a lot of body on this dram. Medium heat that stays for a cup of coffee and not much else, it shows up does it’s job and leaves quickly. The finish is dry like a high tannin wine. 

I really enjoyed this dram. It was exactly what I was expecting of this whiskey which isn’t a bad thing. I’d purchase this again.
It is scotch!  Tasty and easy drinking.

Nose: Peaty with notes of vanilla
Palate: Strong vanilla on a smooth body with notes of stone fruit. Finishes clean
Vanilla honey and pear, like a dry white wine
Seems like the perfect entry scotch. Fruity, vanilla, honey apples. Smooth as a stainless steel. Lovely.

This is my second single malt ever tasted. It is less powerful on the nose than it is at the palate. On the nose you get a light honey and apple note, a lot of cream that resembles vanilla, and a lot of herbal, floral aroma. It is better, way better in the palate. Starts lightly in your tongue then shifts to a hot flavor, with little spices in there with a lovely long beautifil finish, with a little smoke present. As soon as the tasting is over you get this feeling of "this is a great whisky

NOSE: The smell isn't very powerful but you pick up floral with a hint of sweetness

TASTE: You catch lots of pineapple and apple tones. A bit floral with a hint of honey and vanilla sweetness thrown in for good measure. Aftertaste lingers but not for long. The Floral and sweet notes are present and it makes you want more 

Overall a tremendous starter scotch or daily drinker 
80/100
I really like this. Fruit, vanilla, sweet/honey. Not peaty, not too much wood. That's one a buying again for visitors

Color: Honey

Nose: Ripe grapes, cider, vanilla, oak, malt and spice

Palate: Vanilla, oak, ripe grapes, white pepper

Finish: Rounded moderate finish with lovely notes of oak and finally and a dash of spice

Glenlivet 12 is a friendly dram that is vanilla and oak forward with lovely notes of ripe grapes and cider throughout. It's refreshing flavors make it a great bottle to keep around.
Very lovey on the palate; vanilla, fruity. Smooth finish. Excellent value; punches above its weight.

Honey, sweet grass, smooth & creamy.

If chamomile were a whiskey.

I was doing a blind taste test between this and two other whiskies from Portland. After smelling this one, it was clear this was not the Portland whiskey. 

Appearance: clear, light goldish straw color. 

Aroma: clean, lightly toasted grain

Mouthfeel: silky

Flavor: Subtle peat

Finish: Green Apple fades to peat

COLOR/ A light honey, Reminiscent of apple juice
AROMA/ Slight Apple, Slight Floral, Slight Fruits, Banana, Slight Berries, Slight medicinal 
FIRST SIP/ Little Spice, Slight Caramel, Smoothness, Sweetness, Some Oils
TASTE/ All Sorts of Fruits, Sweetness, Complexity, Butterscotch, Slight Wood,
FINISH/ Fruits, Butterscotch, Sweetness, Oils/Butter, Slight Spice, Warming
MT GLASS/ Sweet Wood, Slight Fruit, Slight Maple Syrup
80 proof

Remarks
This is a great beverage over all... I had difficulty deciphering all that there is with this single malt. There are tons of Flavors, Aromas and Complexity deciphering is difficult. It is Very Smooth, Wonderful. And most Enjoyable.
With the addition of water it brings fourth Apple and some peaty-ness.

Be Kind, Be Generous, Be Real, Be Responsible!!!
CH33RS
Light, a little bit spicy, hint of vanilla in the finish. Not complex, but nice for when I want a drink without being challenged.
Tried it on ice. Felt like drinking whiskey. Not peaty. A little sweet. Went down smooth.
Smelled kinda like popcorn, got better with each sip
Tropical fruit with hints of vanilla
Mixed with a lime buddly. Was not great
Sweet and fruit. Proper whisky kick as the caramel hits.
Has a strong whisky flavor but not overpowering, ok to sip but has some sharpness to it. Pretty decent for price ($20 cheaper than the macallan at coco)
Extremely rough going down. Entirely too malty. I will avoid.

Visual: light golden amber color Nose: sweet, vanilla, cereal, graham cracker. Palate: vanilla pudding, creme brûlée. Finish: not super strong finish, lingers a little, similar to palate, cream brûlée.
Faint nose of pears, light bodied, and short finish. Why did I spend money to buy this?
Reasonable priced good go to available everywhere.
honey and fruit tastes with a very light finish

Once more into the sea of Scotch. Glenlivet 12-year-old is a solid welcome to scotch liquid that is found nearly everywhere that sells spirits and the quality is very consistent through the different bottles I have tried. ( Two small, a pint, and a 750ml.) This scotch grew on me as I drank it with my dad and later some friends. It still has the sharpness I associate with scotch but it is a manageable sharpness and with a touch of water or a few small cubes of ice it is actually quite pleasant to drink. The nose is light some fruit and some sweetness there is also some vanilla as well. The body is nice is a bit thin. It is warm and fairly smooth with vanilla and some wood. The finish is light and ends quickly with some wood and lingering sweetness. Overall, this is a nice entry-level scotch to try in my opinion and it will not break the bank. I have read that it has a "generic Speyside" profile and I am not sure what that means. This scotch makes a very nice High ball for a hot June day and for a scotch novice like myself its flavors do not overpower anything when I drink it. Glenmorangie 10yr is still the best tasting scotch I have had so far and a number of people have given me suggestions on the next ones to try and I am slowly getting to those. Lastly, on a personal note, I have read more harsh reviews about this scotch than any others to date and I am amazed by some of the language describing the liquid. I say drink what you want and what you can afford. Enjoy.
Depends on the year on how good it is. Some years I would give it a 3.5 while others a 4.5

Light golden straw color. Nose of orange peel and vanilla. Palette of light smoke, spices and lemon. Mefium-to-long finish. Added water heightened orange and vanilla with palette tasting more caramel.

Nose: Toffee and sea salt. Floral and citrusy. Delicately grassy, like beach grass. Some slight hints of peat. 

Palate: Toffee blending with vanilla. Lemon notes. Some honey as well. Almost tastes the way a hot whiskey does. Slightly malty as well. 

Finish: Medium-long. A little warm. Citrus lingering and keeping it lively. 

Overall Thoughts: Not bad at all! Definitely not one of the best but I can see why Glenlivet is wildly popular all over the world. It’s tasty and very easy to drink. However I wouldn’t say it’s a new favorite and I won’t be rushing out to buy a 750 ml bottle. This is something I’d recommend for someone looking to start trying Scotch. I’m more keen to try some of the older Glenlivet whiskies.
